statement.p:
Recall the following two definitions.
The order of a permutation p is the smallest positive integer k such that p^k is the identity.
A permutation p is an involution if p^2 is the identity permutation.
Note that the identity permutation is an involution. In fact, the identity is the only involution of order 1. The remaining involutions have order 2.
For any k \geq 1, let g_{n,k} be the the number of n-permutations p that are k-volutions, meaning that that p^k is the identity. Let h_{n,k} be the number of n-permutations p of order k. For k >1, we always have g_{n,k} > h_{n,k}, because the identity is a k-volution of order 1 < k.

Let G_k(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} g_{n,k} \frac{x^n}{n!} and H_k(x) = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} h_{n,k} \frac{x^n}{n!} be the exponential generating functions for these sequences. We have
G_1(x) = H_1(x) = \exp(x)
since the identity permutation is the only 1-volution. Example 4.36 on page 202 shows that
G_2(x) = \exp \left( x + \frac{x^2}{2} \right)
and therefore
H_2(x) = \exp \left( x + \frac{x^2}{2} \right) - \exp\left( x \right)
Find G_3(x) and H_3(x).
Find G_4(x) and H_4(x).
Let k \geq 1 and suppose that p^k is the identity. Explain why the order of p must divide k. Use this fact to find a formula for G_k(x).
Find a formula for H_{6}(x) in terms of G_{k}(x) where 1 \leq k \leq 6.
Find a formula for H_{30}(x) in terms of G_{k}(x) where 1 \leq k \leq 30.
